body: Looks good, merged into trunk. Thanks.
/cc @sebgoa
Patch merged into trunk. Thanks.
I went ahead and manually merged the changes into trunk. Thanks.
Merged into trunk. Thanks.
LGTM, +1

@Kami - sorry to sneak another one in after your review.  This one-liner is actually an unrelated bug fix, but I was thinking it's so small it didn't merit it's own issue and PR.  But let me know if you prefer if this was split out.

@erjohnso No problem.

Also, while we are at it, it would make sense to add `_get_record_id(self, record_type, record_name)` and use that instead of repeating the logic (it makes it easier to change it in the future and maybe even move it to the base driver).

@Kami - Ok, you were correct that it wasn't matching the model, iiuc.  Google doesn't use numerical ID's in the API other than as informational output, so I think using the 'name' field as the 'id' is a much better fit between libcloud's model and Google's API.  But I did tuck the numerical 'id' into the 'extra' struct.

I was less confident in my ability to refactor base as you suggested.  Plus this is getting to be a big enough change that it's diverting more from the original goal (just swap out '-' with ':').

@erjohnso Hm, looking at the API docs you should be able to use either (name or the id) in the zone case - `Identifies the managed zone addressed by this request. Can be the managed zone name or ID.`.

In any case, I'm fine with using `name`.

Oh, sorry about the inconsistency, I've overlooked that in the original patch.

LGTM too.
Thanks @franckcuny and @Kami.  I've squashed the commit, generated the patch, and uploaded it to Jira issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-551
Merged into trunk. Thanks.

@bouttier Looks good, but can you please add some test cases for this change (`OS-EXT-IPS:type` not being present, `OS-EXT-IPS:type` being set to `floating`, `OS-EXT-IPS:type` being set to a value different than `floating`)?

I'm not sure of how add test cases, theses values depends of openstack version (rackspace used in tests files apparently). I think `floating` and `fixed` cases are already tested by existing tests ; if `OS-EXT-IPS:type` is not set, I use `get` function so `ip_type = None != 'floating'`.
@bouttier For testing we use response fixtures - you can find a bunch of examples in `libcloud/test/compute/`.

@bouttier Actually, I just checked at your pull description and OpenStack docs again and I don't actually think we want this in trunk - why would you want to see private IP as public (it seems like this should be handled in the code which uses Libcloud and not in the Libcloud itself)?

Also, addresses should already be correctly split in the "private" and "public" attribute.
@tomprince bump^^

In my case, I had an issue with salt-cloud who want remove the public key  from .ssh/know_host on vm deletion. For that, salt-cloud search the first public ip (and I used an old version of libcloud that I fix in my way). I understand your point of view and I will search an other way in salt-cloud to select the right ip.
@bouttier One thing we could do to make this easier for you it to store information about floating and fixed IP addresses in the Node `extra` attribute.
fixed doc

Merged into trunk, thanks.

P.S. The reason prices are already there is because pricing information is automatically fetched and parsed from the AWS website by the`./contrib/` script. Sadly Amazon doesn't provide an API endpoint for retrieving sizes information so we can't use that approach for sizes.
Sorry for the delay. This has now been merged into trunk. Thanks.
Adding some tests for this new functionality would be good.

Something is wrong with the tests:

Providing VPC IDs and filters returns correct number of matching objects  when working with EC2 API. In tests the calls return all objects in the fixture (ignores the filter)

Please advice!

Merged into trunk.

Thanks.

Merged into trunk.

Thanks.

I went ahead, squashed the commits, fixed the tests and merged changes into trunk.

The problem in your case was that you asserted on the response, but you returned the same fixture which contains all the networks. I've changed the tests to assert that the correct query parameters are sent, because that's the thing we are actually interested in and want to test in this case.

This seems to be related to #291, right? (/cc @bouttier)

It seems the best approach would be to do something like described in my last comment - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/291#issuecomment-43046177
I haven't had time to find the best way to modify salt yet, but yes this can be useful, and not only for me apparently (#296).

> If domain is not required anymore, can we just get rid of this argument all together (backward incompatible)?

Sure, it can be removed. Most projects I work with give at least one release with a `DeprecationWarnging` before making incompatible changes. This way, they can upgrade without making any changes to the code, test, and then make changes to get rid of the warnings.

Merged into trunk.

Thanks.

I've made some changes and fixes and merged this patch into trunk.

Hopefully, security group API promotion will be implemented soon and then we can deprecate and get rid of this method all together.

Looks good. Merged into trunk.

Thanks.
Thanks, Kami
@magnusart - thanks Magnus!  Sorry for the laggy LGTM. :)

I updated three commits:
- "Fix publickey._to_md5_fingerprint for Python 3": added a unit test.
- "Fix publickey.get_pubkey_ssh2_fingerprint for Python 3": use our own py3.bchr function.
- "Add "floating IP" functions to the OpenStack provider": instead of using a handler, I added IP address handler methods directory to the driver class. I used the method name you mentioned, I don't find it's confusing.
  
  I had to add a "driver" parameter to the OpenStack_1_1_FloatingIpAddress class so that the object can use it to delete itself. I didn't want to use the "pool" object for this, I felt that that would be more confusing. Suggestions about better solutions are welcome.

I've squashed the commits, fixed some lint issues and merged your changes into trunk.

Thanks!

Yeah, I agree that it would be better to use a name which is not a built in function.

The problem though it that some base methods and classes use `id` for the name where changing it would break backward compatibility and making it painful for users to migrate / update their code.

Btw, I just had a look and your fork and pull request seem out of that.

It looks like the version in trunk is already using `group_id` in the method signature - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/ec2.py#L4584
@sasi5a1 ^^ what do you think about my comment and the approach suggested there?

@hcs42 Btw, I know this has already been merged, but what do you think about this approach - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-567?focusedCommentId=14012135&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-14012135 ?
Thanks! I posted my opinion in the JIRA ticket.

Yes, this was fixed in https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/301 which was merged before this one.
Closing.

Hmm... not sure what to do about those travis failures,

``` sh
WARNING:test command found but not installed in testenv
```

I don't think it has anything to do with my changes and if it does, I'm at a loss on how to interpret the error.

Looking at the differences between base and overloaded constructor - base constructor also lower cases the header keys, but it seems like RimuHosting driver never accesses `response.headers` properly so the driver shouldn't be affected by this.

Also, I don't have RimuHosting account so I can't test those changes myself. Have you actually tested those changes with the RimuHosting API and can confirm that they are working?

Thanks
We'll be cancelling this and submitting a PR using the Jira issue ID.
Yes, I was able to successfully bring up a Rimu compute node with/without libcloud debugging. Stepped through the request/response in the debugger and the driver was correctly handling the response.
@amastracci I noticed you closed this pull request. Was this intentional? Or can I proceed and merge it?
@Kami - I think this is good to go unless you want to hear from @wrigri or @franckcuny.
Looks good to me
Pilot error. Yes go ahead and merge it up.

Merged into trunk.

Thanks.

Fix looks good. While we are at it, this is also a good opportunity to improve the existing code and remove some unnecessary duplication.

We could save a couple of lines by, pre-defining `vps_parameters` to an empty dict (unless RimuHosting API doesn't like if you send them an empty dict):

``` python
data = {
            'instantiation_options': {
                'domain_name': name, 'distro': image.id
            },
            'vps_parameters': {},
            'pricing_plan_code': size.id,
        }
...
```

This way we can get rid of duplicated `'vps_parameters' not in data` check.

It would also be good to add some tests to make sure that correct parameters are sent to the provider (not a blocker for this pull request).

Lint is failing, besides that, LGTM.

/cc @cderamus

LGTM.

/cc @cderamus

Yes, just some trailing whitespace - https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/jobs/26680711#L48

I've merged it into trunk with a minor fix - I've changed the default value for `scopes` attribute from `[]` to `None` and initialized empty list inside the function.

The problem is that default values for arguments are created at the time of the function definition. This means that if you would mutate `scope` argument inside the function, you would actually be mutating the default parameter value which is almost never something you would want.

Good catch. I'll merge it into trunk tomorrow. 

Thanks.

Merged into trunk.

Thanks.

Sorry for the delay. I've merged the changes into trunk. Thanks.

On a related note -

There were a couple of other spots which also didn't use keyword arguments and specify a `driver` argument, so I also updated those. This is also a good example of why always using keyword arguments is a good idea - it doesn't just make code more readable / clear, but it also prevents issues like this from happening :)

> Sorry for the delay.

No worries :)

> On a related note -

I totally agree.

Fixed the Keypar stuff that @Kami brougth to my attention. Im guessing that the way of storing extra stuff for the Keypairs is to use the extra field, so that's where I stored the ID of the key :D
